title: Writing in Art and Culture : DABUS DANCE

Ng Kea Chye, Gerald (2016). Violin in Ensemble for Dance: Improvisatory Styles in the 'Adopted' Malay Dances of Zapin. Studia Instrumentorum Musicae Popularis IV (New Series). Edited by Gisa Jähnichen. Münster: MV-Wissenschaft, 217-224
Commemorating the Singapore-Medan Connection: Contradictions in Appropriating “Indonesian” Repertories into the Singapore Malay Dance Canon
summary:
In the recent decade, there have been discussions amongst the community of Singapore Malay dance practitioners regarding the incorporation of the Sembilan Tari Wajib, Nine Obligatory Dances, which were choreographed by the North Sumatran dance personality, Sauti, and later popularized and packaged by his students into the existing canon of the five Malay dance basics of Singapore (Asli, Inang, Joget, Masri and Zapin).  This intention was met with much contestation by those who oppose that the community continues to draw upon its historical “Melayu Deli” (modern-day North Sumatran) connection which was established in the early fifties, even decades after attaining Singapore nationhood.
 
This paper retraces the sociopolitical circumstances of these transnational artistic relations which were the result of a burgeoning Malay nationalism and the endorsement of the movement by Malay artists through their arts organizations in Singapore.  I juxtapose this with contemporary activities and commemoration of the “Singapore-Medan connection” that contradicts the community’s incessant desire for a distinctly Singapore Malay dance identity in the face of nationalistic standardization of dances by neighboring countries, Indonesia and Malaysia.
 
The paper draws upon archival investigation and my recent ethnographic fieldwork in Medan (2015) and Singapore (2017-2018). I also include my experience as an insider within the Singapore Malay Dance community where I have been a dance practitioner since 2003.

title: [Web Article] Flashback: Seven Decades of Malay Dance in Singapore
summary: How did Singapore Malay dance come about? As with most things cultural, its journey can be traced back to even before Singapore officially became a nation. We look at some milestones in this uniquely Singapore art form and identify its movers and shakers.

title: [Book Chapter] Creativity Through Tradition: An Appreciation of Malay Dance  at Polytechnic Level in Singapore
[Book Chapter] Tari Melayu Ala Singapura: Reflections on Singapore’s Nationalising of Malay Folk Dances of Maritime Southeast Asia
Intersections, Interjections and Interplay: A Reflection on International Collaborative Dance Making
summary:
Presenting under his stage alias Soultari, this lecture presents reflections as a facilitator and collaborator in collaborative ‘dance making’ with dance artists from various cultural background and dance disciplines. As a traditional practitioner and choreographer of Malay dance, Soultari’s experience in collaborating with artists from outside Singapore only started during his postgraduate studies in Europe (2014 to present).

In this lecture, he will share some of his ‘culture shock’ dealing with artists who are trained in Western Dance technique. He will highlight some of their feedback on Soultari’s ‘traditional’ choreographic approach in his maiden international project in the UK entitled Bhumi which was presented at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2016.

In addition, he will share how a high degree of reflexivity after his first experience has helped him re-fashion his own methods in facilitating collaboration for his next artistic collaborative project entitled “Sonder”, a collaboration with Classical musicians from the Royal College of Music, UK, and dance artists from Palestine/Jordan and Kyrgyzstan (UK, 2017).

Acknowledging that the experience is never the same from one project to the next, Soultari is determined to pinpoint the intersections, interjections and interplay that happens in collaborative ‘dance making’ which has served to shift the focus from product-driven practices to a process-centred one.

title: Creativity Through Tradition: Appreciation of Malay Dance at Polytechnic Level
summary:
This paper examines the use of creative movement in the teaching and practice of traditional Malay dance to polytechnic students in Singapore. Malay dance is offered as an optional Co-Curricular Activity (CCA) at Polytechnics for interested participants aged 17-22 years old.

Incorporating his experience as a choreographer and arts educator, Amin Farid shares his strategies in teaching and motivating young practitioners of Malay dance in the tertiary sector for more than a decade.

Most of these young adults who enter the CCA at a tertiary level, would have experienced dance at a secondary school level which are usually structured and rigid in preparation for participation in Singapore Youth Festival – a national “competition”. The employment of creative movement strategies to learn traditional dance enables students to develop the capacity to be expressive beyond fixed boundaries.

Amin employs choreographic tools that was taught by his Guru who was inspired by the teachings of renowned Indonesian dance maestro, late Bagong Kussudiardjo. Adapting indigenous practice and terms such as Gerak (Movement), Bentuk (Form), Jiwa (Feeling) and Harmoni (Harmony), he shares how creativity can be encouraged through tradition to encourage young practitioners to become movement creators to create their own choreography when they improvise and create their own vocabulary of traditional work.

title: Traditional Dance Forms in Dialogue: Performance-Lecture as Intercultural and Critical Performance Practice in the Nation-State
summary:
The performance-lecture or the lecture-performance as a mode of artistic presentation is gaining in currency. In the field of dance, this mode of presentation saw prominence through French choreographer, Jérôme Bel, who has adopted this mode of performance, “exposing systematic structures in the dance industry, more directly than he has found possible through movements of the body alone” (Milder 13-14).

This paper aims to demonstrate how the Performance-Lecture as a presentation mode provides an opportunity for intercultural and interdisciplinary dialogue. The author argues that this mode of performance brings to the fore critical discourse on dance forms that have been influenced by nation-building agendas, arts policies and transnational trends. In addition via the performance lecture, stereotypical ideas of the “traditional” dance artist is subverted, providing him/her agency and empowerment to articulate perspectives.

Reflecting upon his recent experience, the author provides his recent performance-lecture, a collaboration with another dance researcher-practitioner, as a case study.  As young dance scholars in the field of Malay and Chinese dance respectively, they have observed that the practitioners of their “traditional” dance forms, have not been in dialogue with each other since the foundational years of Singapore as a nation-state in 1965. Acknowledging this lack of artistic and intellectual conversations, the performance-lecture entitled, “Intersections: Traditionally Speaking” (March 2018) allowed them to investigate, question, critique and collaborate.

As Art critic Patricia Milder affirms, “the best lecture-performances always seem to originate from artists who believe that teaching itself is a central component of their artwork” (13). This is true for the collaborators who are also dance educators with reasonable insider experiences to their respective “art worlds” (Becker et al): well-informed of the common pedagogy employed, therefore providing intercultural perspectives which are equally engaging and nuanced.
